vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Organization Management in VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
Organization ManagementLast Updated December 16, 2025Use **VCF Automation** as a cloud administrator (or organization administrator) to set up projects for application teams, allocate resources, and apply governance.In VCF Automation, an organization is a top level entity that represents a line of business or a tenant. Each organization operates in a secure and isolated environment where users can access only allocated services and resources. Organizations consume resources and cloud services from a shared pool of resources. The resources allocated to organizations can be further allocated to application teams which are modeled in VCF Automation as projects. Organizations have users with varying levels of permissions depending on their role and duties.Organizations in VCF Automation are created by the provider administrator in the VCF Automation Provider Management Portal. The provider administrator can create two types of organizations: an All Apps organization and a VM Apps organization. VM Apps organizations can run VM-based applications, while All Apps organizations are enabled to run a comprehensive set of built-in cloud services. For more information about creating VCF Automation organizations in the provider portal, see Managing Organizations.Regardless of the type, each organization has its own organization portal where users log in to consume resources and services. Every organization has its own identity source that they connect to and can import users from.All Apps Organizations in VCF AutomationAll Apps оrganizations offer application teams a comprehensive set of built-in cloud services to provision VMs, Kubernetes, networking, volumes, Secret Store, databases, Harbor container registries, external DNS, certificates, and AI workloads. These cloud services can be consumed on a self-service basis through a curated catalog or self-service interfaces.Organizations enable line-of-business or tenant organization administrators to further organize and govern resources that are allocated to them among application teams through the following capabilities: Resource management for project teams. Centralized content management for the organization. Policy-based governance on usage of resources. Quota-based management of networking resources. Workflow orchestration and extensibility through event subscriptions. Integration with identity providers of their choice.
For information on working with All Apps organizations, see the Managing Organizations for All Apps in guide.Provider Consumption Organizations in VCF AutomationA Provider Consumption organization (PCO) is a special type of All Apps organization in VCF Automation that the provider administrator enables in the VCF Automation
 Provider Management Portal. The provider administrator can enable only one Provider Consumption organization. For more information about PCOs, see Create a Provider Consumption Organization.The PCO is intended for use when the provider wants to have their own consumption service for their users and/or they want to share catalog items with other organizations under their management.PCOs are administered in the same way as other All Apps organizations, but they offer some additional capabilities on top of what a standard All Apps organization provides. PCOs come with a preconfigured  VCF Operations orchestrator  instance that is embedded in the organization portal, which you access on the  Orchestrate  tab. As a PCO administrator, you can publish  VCF Operations orchestrator  objects as catalog items to other organizations that use the same embedded  VCF Operations orchestrator  instance. You can publish catalog items to other organizations that use VM images from a provider content library. For more information about managing your VCF Operations orchestrator
 integration, see Managing VMware Cloud Foundation Operations Orchestrator.VM Apps Organizations in VCF AutomationVM Apps organizations help existing VMware Aria Automation users transition to VCF Automation 9.0 without any impact to infrastructure, automation, or end-user experience.In VM Apps organizations, the allocation of resources, like cloud accounts, cloud zones, profiles, image mappings and so on, is contained in the organization itself. The organization administrator defines and works with the infrastructure; the provider administrator does not allocate resources to organization of this type.If you upgrade an existing VMware Aria Automation 8.x deployment to VCF Automation 9, your organizations are automatically mapped to VCF Automation for VM Apps organizations. You continue to use vIDB and VMware Aria Suite Lifecycle to manage vIDM to maintain legacy authentication.
For information on working with VM Apps organizations, see the Managing Organizations in for VM Apps guide.Best Practices for Organizations in VCF AutomationWhen to use All Apps vs VM Apps? All Apps organizations are used when organizations are ready to leverage the comprehensive set of built-in cloud services to provision VMs, Kubernetes, and so on. The underlying infrastructure requires vSphere Supervisor clusters and is managed in the  VCF Automation  Provider Management Portal. Talk to your provider administrator about how you can leverage these capabilities. VM Apps organizations are intended for current users of VMware Aria Automation who want to continue their journey with minimal disruptions. The VM Apps organization is fully self-contained with built-in infrastructure management and consumption capabilities. When to use blueprints vs the IaaS self-service console? Blueprints and the catalog offer a controlled manner to build and curate infrastructure. They are prescriptive in terms of the provisioned resources and so are suitable to deploy applications in production. They are also suitable for end users who do not want to concern themselves with details of the infrastructure. The IaaS self-service console offers more flexibility and is more suitable for development purposes.

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Predefined User Roles in VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
Roles assigned to users and groups are an essential part to identity and access management in VCF Automation. You can leverage identity providers with VCF Automation organizations to enable single sign-on to provision users and groups. Once the users and groups are added to the VCF Automation organization, they must be assigned roles to enable specific permissions and access to different features within VCF Automation.What are User Roles in VCF AutomationVCF Automation has several levels of user roles. These different levels control access to the organization, the projects that produce or consume the blueprints, catalog items, access to IaaS services, and the ability for users to use or see individual parts of the user interface. These different levels give organization administrators different tools to apply any level of granularity that is required by their operational needs.As the organization administrator, after you configure an identity provider for your organization, you can import users and groups and manage their role assignments using the Access Control page. There are two types of predefined roles in VCF Automation: organization roles and project roles. In addition, you can create custom roles for specific use cases.Predefined Organization RolesThe organization roles are global. The predefined organization-level roles are Organization Administrator, Organization Auditor, and Organization User.Organizational roles define permissions within the organization. Organization administrators can add and manage other users and create custom roles at the organization level. Custom roles allow you to tailor permissions to specific user requirements.Predefined organization-level roles are managed by the provider administrator in the VCF Automation Provider Management Portal. For a full list of what rights are given to each role, see Predefined VCF Automation Roles and Their Rights in the Provider Management documentation.Custom Organization RolesAs an organization administrator, you can create custom roles for your organization.The custom roles have two categories, view and manage. View. A user assigned to a role with this permission can see all the items for all projects across the organization in the selected sections of the user interface. This role is useful for users who need to see accounts, configurations, or assigned values. Manage. A user assigned to a role with this permission can see all the items and has full add, edit, and delete permissions for all projects across the organization in the selected sections of the user interface. These permissions extend the privileges that are granted by the other roles and are not restricted by project membership. For example, you can expand a project administrator's permissions to manage parts of the infrastructure or give an organization auditor an ability to review and respond to approvals requests.
For instructions on how to create a custom role, see Create a Custom Role in for All Apps.Project RolesIn addition to the organizational roles, VCF Automation has project roles. Project members can view and manage project resources depending on their project role. Project roles include Project Administrator, Project Advanced User, Project User, and Project Auditor.These roles are assigned automatically on a per project basis in VCF Automation. The project roles can vary between projects. The same user can be an administrator in one project and an advanced user in another project.

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Configuring VCF Automation as an OIDC Proxy Server
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
You can use VCF Automation as a tenant-aware OpenId Connect (OIDC) identity provider proxy server. Verify that your role includes the  OIDC Server: Manage Settings  right. Verify that the roles of the users that will log in to the OIDC relying party (OIDC client) through  VCF Automation  include the  OIDC Server: Enable  right. After you configure VCF Automation as an OIDC proxy server, when a user attempts to log in to the OIDC relying party (OIDC client), they are redirected to VCF Automation and prompted to enter the name of their organization and their SSO or local credentials. After providing the necessary credentials, the user is directed to the OIDC relying party.VCF Automation delegates actual authentication to the authentication mechanism used by the provider or organization. This can result in additional redirects to any external Identity Providers that perform authentication for those users.Do not delete the automation-relying-party item in the Relying Parties list on the OIDC Services page. automation-relying-party is necessary for the organization portal services. Log in to the  VCF Automation Provider Management Portal . From the left navigation panel, select  OIDC Services . Click  Relying Parties  and click  New . Enter a relying party name for the client application registration, and make a note of it. Enter the URI to which to redirect users that are attempting to log in to the relying party, and click  Save . Copy the relying party ID and secret, and make note of them. Configure your OIDC relying party to use  VCF Automation  as an identity provider proxy server with the relying party ID and secret. You can retrieve the provider configuration values, including the JWKS endpoint and information about other endpoints and scopes necessary for the OIDC proxy configuration at the well-known configuration URL  hostname /oidc/.well-known/openid-configuration . See View and Edit the OIDC Proxy General Settings in Your VCF Automation. When a user attempts to log in to the OIDC relying party, they are redirected to VCF Automation, prompted to select a VCF Automation organization, and to provide their credentials. After a successful authorization, they are redirected back to the OIDC relying party.
You can use the vertical ellipsis () menu next to the name of the relying party ID to edit and delete the relying party, to regenerate a secret, and to copy the relying party ID.

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Enabling PKCE with vIDB in VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
VCF Automation supports Proof Key for Code Exchange (PKCE).Verify that you configured your system to use an OpenID Connect Identity Provider. See Configure Your System to Use an OpenID Connect Identity Provider Using Your VCF Automation Provider Management Portal.
PKCE is an extension to the OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code flow that is used to prevent CSRF and authorization code injection attacks. For more information, see Proof Key for Code Exchange in the OAuth 2.0 documentation. Run the request to retrieve your organization's settings. GET https://vcfa.example.com/api/admin/org/organization_id/settings/oauth The response contains the OAuth settings for your organization. Under  OrgOAuthSettings , make the following changes. Modify the  usePkce  element to  true . If your identity provider requires that client credentials be sent as an authorization header when making the API request to retrieve the access token, modify the  sendClientCredentialsAsAuthorizationHeader  element to  true . The default behavior is for the client credentials to be sent in the body of the API request. To update your OAuth settings with your modifications, run a PUT request. PUT https://vcfa.example.com/api/admin/org/organization_id/settings/oauth In the body of the request, include the modified elements of your OAuth settings.

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Generating API Access Tokens using vIDB
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description: You can generate and issue API access tokens. You are authenticated using your respective security best practices, including leveraging two-factor authorization, by using API access tokens, you can grant access for building automation against VCF Automation.Authenticating with an API token uses the "Refreshing an Access Token" standard as specified in the OAuth 2.0 RFC 6749 Section 6 to allow access to VCF Automation as an OAuth application. The returned access token is the same as a VCF Automation access token and client applications can use it to make subsequent API calls to VCF Automation. To make an OAuth 2.0 RFC-compliant request, familiarize yourself with Request for Comments (RFC) 6749 Section 6 information about refreshing an access token.Access tokens are artifacts that client applications use to make API requests on behalf of a user. Applications need access tokens for authentication. When an access token expires, to obtain access tokens, applications can use API tokens. By default, API tokens expire after 90 days.When using access tokens, applications cannot perform certain tasks. Change the user password Perform user management tasks Create more tokens View or revoke other tokens When accessing VCF Automation by using an API access token, applications have only view rights for the following resources. User Group Roles Global roles Rights bundles Applications accessing VCF Automation by using an API access token do not have the following rights. Token: Manage Token: Manage All Similar to generating a user API token, you can create a service account by using the VCF Automation API. The API request for creating a service account uses the same API endpoint as creating a user API token, but the presence of the software_id field indicates the intent to create a service account. In the upper right corner of the navigation bar, click your user name, and select  My Account . Under the  API Tokens  section, click  New . Enter a name for the token, and click  Create . The generated API token appears. You must copy the token because it appears only once. After you click  OK , you cannot retrieve this token again, you can only revoke it. Make an OAuth 2.0 RFC-compliant request to the  https:// site.cloud.example.com /oauth/provider/token  API endpoint. The request returns an access token that applications can use to perform tasks in  VCF Automation . The token is valid even after the user logs out. When an access token expires, the application can obtain more access tokens by using the API token. Request:POST https://host_name/oauth/provider/token Accept: application/json Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded Content-Length: 71 grant_type=refresh_token&refresh_token=Generated_API_Token Response:HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/json { "access_token":"Generated_Access_Token", "token_type":"Bearer", "expires_in":2592000, "refresh_token":null } Request using the generated access token:GET https://host_name/cloudapi/1.0.0/orgs Accept: application/json;version=40.0 Authorization: Bearer Generated_Access_Token Response:{"resultTotal":1,"pageCount":1,"page":1,"pageSize":25,"associations":[{"entityId":"urn:vcloud:org:a11a11a1-1111-1111-1a11","associationId":"a11a11a1-1111-1111-1a11@a11a1a11-1111-1111-1a11"}],"values":[{"id":"urn:vcloud:org:a11a1a11-1111-1111-1a11-a1a11aa11a1","name":"System","displayName":"System","description":"System Bucket","isEnabled":true,"managedBy":null,"canManageOrgs":true,"maskedEventTaskUsername":"system","directlyManagedOrgCount":0,"isClassicTenant":false,"isProviderConsumptionOrg":false,"creationStatus":"READY"}]}% If you want tenants to be able to generate tokens, you must grant tenant roles the  Manage user's own API token  right. By default, tenant users see only the tokens they create. To allow organization administrators to see and revoke the tokens of the other tenant users in the organization, you must grant them the  Manage all users' API tokens  right. Administrators with the  Manage all users' API tokens  right can see only the names of other users' the tokens, not the tokens themselves. To revoke any of your tokens, navigate to the  User preferences  page, and click the vertical ellipsis next to the token. To revoke the tokens of other users, in the top navigation bar, under  Administration , navigate to the access control settings for users. When selecting a specific user, you can also see their access tokens and revoke them. If you must identify events triggered by the use of an API access token, in the event log the following line appears in the  additionalProperties  section of an event. ```default "currentContext.refreshTokenId": "<UUID_of_the_token_that_performed_the_action>

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Managing Identity Providers with vIDB
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
You can integrate your VCF Automation with one or more external identity providers (IdPs), and import users and groups to your organizations. You can configure an LDAP server connection at the system or the organization level, a SAML integration at the organization level, and an OpenID Connect (OIDC) integration at the organization level.To determine the correct values and settings and to ensure proper and accurate configuration, see also the product documentation of those identity providers.You can also use the VCF Operations provider identity configuration, making VIDB the identity provider. See VCF Single Sign-On Models and Configuring VCF Single Sign-On. If you already have an OIDC connection for the provider organization, you cannot connect to VCF
VKS Single Sign-On (SSO). You must remove the OIDC configuration to configure VCF SSO. If you configure VCF SSO, a VCF SSO tab replaces the OIDC tab on the Identity Providers page.An organization can define an identity provider that it shares with other applications. Users authenticate to the identity provider to obtain a token that they can then use to log in to the organization. Such a strategy can enable an enterprise to provide access to multiple, unrelated services, including VCF Automation, with a single set of credentials, an arrangement often referred to as single sign-on.You can integrate your VCF Automation organizations with more than one identity provider. You must not have identical user names across IdPs. You can have only one integration per IdP technology. For example, you can have one LDAP, one SAML, and one OpenID Connect (OIDC) integration simultaneously. The login page displays all configured sign-in options and to make the login more user friendly, you can customize the button labels from the IdP edit pages.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Automation/Tenancy and Access Control/VCF Identity Broker/Managing Identity Providers with vIDB.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Managing IDPs
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description: As an organization administrator, you can use one or more external identity providers to import and manage users and groups in your organization. You can configure an LDAP server connection, a SAML integration, and an OpenID Connect (OIDC) integration.VCF Automation supports user login with an identity providers directly. Any third-party provider with OIDC, SAML, AD/LDAP protocols can be configured to use Single Sign-on to VCF Automation for identity and access management.

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Remapping VCF Automation Users Between Identity Providers
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description: You can remap VCF Automation users between identity providers.You can remap individual users from one identity provider (IDP) to another by using the VCF Automation API. You can use the VCF Automation UI for bulk remapping of users between identity providers.You can use the VCF Automation UI for bulk remapping of users between identity providers. Verify that your role includes the Group / User: Manage  right. Verify that the organization is configured with the identity provider types that you want to remap between. Log in to the  VCF Automation Provider Management Portal . From the primary left navigation panel, select  Access Control . Select  Users . Click  Bulk Update . Click  Export Users . The users are exported into a CSV file. In the CSV file with the users, change the value in the  providerType  field to identify the new IdP for each user. VCF Automation  supports the  SAML ,  LDAP , and  OAUTH  values. To remap a user to an OIDC identity provider, you must change the value in the  providerType  field to  OAUTH . To match the user name in the IdP that each user is remapping to, modify the user name. For  VCF Automation  to continue to associate the user's assets with the user when they log in through the new login flow, the ID of the user must remain unchanged. Changes to all other fields are ignored. Save your changes and close the CSV file. In the  Users Bulk Update  wizard, click  Next . Click  Select CSV File , browse for the file, and upload it. Click  Next . Click  Update . When you start the update process, users are remapped one by one. Users for which no changes are detected are skipped. If you close the  VCF Automation  UI tab while before the process is complete, the update stops. You can remap individual users from one identity provider (IdP) to another by using the VCF Automation API. Verify that your role includes the Group / User: Manage  right. Verify that the organization is configured with the identity provider types that you want to remap between. For information about bulk remapping of users between identity providers by using the VCF Automation UI, see Remap Users Between Identity Providers Using Your VCF Automation Provider Management Portal. Make a GET request to  /cloudapi/1.0.0/users . VCF Automation  returns a list of the users within the organization. Locate the user you want to remap, and retrieve the user information. GET /cloudapi/1.0.0/users/{user_id} Make a PUT request to  /cloudapi/1.0.0/users/ {user_id} . To remap a user, you must change the  providerType  field to identify the new IDP.  VCF Automation  supports the  SAML ,  LDAP , and  OAUTH  values. Additionally, to match the user name in the IDP that the user is remapping to, you can modify the user name. For  VCF Automation  to continue to associate the user's assets with the user when they log in through the new login flow, the ID of the user must remain unchanged. If you are remapping to provider type  LDAP ,  VCF Automation  validates the user name with the LDAP server before committing the operation. If  VCF Automation  does not complete this step for any reason, for example, loss of connectivity to the LDAP server, the remapping fails. If you are remapping a user to be a local user by specifying provider type  LOCAL , similar to the process of creating a user, you must provide a password. Verify that  VCF Automation  returns an  OK  response specifying the newly remapped provider type in the response body. To find the user that you want to remap, make the following request.Request:GET /cloudapi/1.0.0/users?pageSize=10 HTTP/1.1 Host: 127.0.0.1:8443 Accept: application/json;version=37.1 Sample response:{ "resultTotal": 2, "pageCount": 1, "page": 1, "pageSize": 10, "associations": null, "values": [ ..., { "username": "testuser", "fullName": "", "description": null, "id": "urn:vcloud:user:2b038199-0063-4c13-9bba-a3b58d775785", "roleEntityRefs": [ { "name": "vApp Author", "id": "urn:vcloud:role:85f69506-52a5-3e20-869a-ea18d667e19e" } ], "orgEntityRef": { "name": "testorg", "id": "urn:vcloud:org:806f0d87-c8b9-47f5-bfbe-3dc73a4c0d14" }, "password": "******", "email": "", "nameInSource": "testuser", "enabled": true, "isGroupRole": false, "providerType": "LOCAL" } ] } To remap testuser from LOCAL to LDAP, make a PUT request.Request:PUT /cloudapi/1.0.0/users/urn:vcloud:user:2b038199-0063-4c13-9bba-a3b58d775785 HTTP/1.1 Host: 127.0.0.1:8443 Accept: application/json;version=37.1 Content-Type: application/json;version=37.1 Body: { "username": "testuser", "fullName": "", "description": null, "id": "testorg", "id": "urn:vcloud:org:806f0d87-c8b9-47f5-bfbe-3dc73a4c0d14" }, "password": "******", "email": "", "nameInSource": "testuser", "enabled": true, "isGroupRole": false, "providerType": "LDAP" } "urn:vcloud:role:85f69506-52a5-3e20-869a-ea18d667e19e" } ], "orgEntityRef": { "name": "testorg", "id": "urn:vcloud:org:806f0d87-c8b9-47f5-bfbe-3dc73a4c0d14" }, "password": null, "email": "", vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Using VCF Automation as an Identity Provider Proxy Server
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
ou can take advantage of the OIDC Services to use VCF Automation as a tenant-aware identity provider proxy server.When VCF Automation is configured as an identity provider proxy server by using the OAuth 2.0 OpenID Connect standard, relying parties can use VCF Automation for tenant-aware authentication of users known to VCF Automation. For detailed information on the OpenID Connect standard, see OpenID Connect Core 1.0.As an identity provider proxy server, VCF Automation acts as intermediary between the client application (relying party) and the identity provider, and delegates actual authentication to the respective authentication mechanism used by the provider or tenants.A system administrator can configure relying parties that integrate with VCF Automation and then enable individual organizations to allow their users to use VCF Automation as an identity provider proxy.When making browser-based requests to the /oidc endpoints, the default behavior is for browser pages to be loaded from the VCF Automation host. To use OIDC, you can also configure a non-VCF Automation host into the CORS filtering list.Authentication FlowIntegration with VCF Automation
 is implemented through the OAuth 2.0 OIDC authorization code flow standard. For detailed information, see Authentication using the Authorization Code Flow.When a relying party redirects a user to VCF Automation, if there is no existing client session, the user is prompted to log in to VCF Automation by first identifying the organization or provider portal they wish to log into. The user authenticates through the configured authentication mechanism, which may involve further redirections to external identity providers. If the user's browser detects an existing VCF Automation user session, the authentication flow provides an SSO experience and no user interaction is required for reauthentication. Upon successful completion of the process, VCF Automation returns an access token and an ID token. The authorization code that is issued as part of the flow is valid for 5 minutes. The access token is valid for 5 minutes, and the ID token is valid for an hour.You cannot use the access token that VCF Automation returns upon successful authentication for accessing the UI portals or for making regular VCF Automation API calls.ID Token DetailsThe ID token that VCF Automation returns contains the following OpenID standard claims and VCF Automation specific claims.OpenID Request ScopesThe scope of the OpenID request is used to specify the privileges requested for an access token.Endpoints
You can use the access token returned by  VCF Automation  to retrieve claims about the authenticated user at the  hostname /oidc/UserInfo  endpoint. For details, see UserInfo Endpoint.
You can retrieve the provider configuration values, including the JWKS endpoint and information about other endpoints and scopes necessary for the OIDC proxy configuration at the well-known configuration URL  hostname /oidc/.well-known/openid-configuration . See View and Edit the OIDC Proxy General Settings in Your VCF Automation. Token Exchange Access to VCF Automation Identity Provider ProxyProgrammatic integration with the identity provider proxy functionality of VCF Automation is available through the token exchange flow that is detailed below. This flow does not involve the VCF Automation UI and is suitable for scripted access, such as CLI. Obtain a  VCF Automation  JWT by either directly logging in or by using an API token. Run a POST request. POST hostname/oidc/oauth2/token Select  x-www-form-urlencoded  for the body of the request. Include the following parameters in the body of the request. { "grant_type": "urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:jwt-bearer", "assertion": "VMware_Cloud_Director JWT", "client_id": "Relying_party_ID", "scope": "openid profile email phone groups vcd_idp", } The response returns both an ID token that includes the OIDC and  VCF Automation  claims, and an access token that you can use to retrieve claims about the authenticated user at the  hostname /oidc/UserInfo  endpoint. Encoded ID token example:eyJhbGciOiJSUzI1NiIsInR5NDg4SI6I................4dHnbU1RQ6Y9Yohgw Decoded ID token example:{ "at_hash": "1AA1aAA1AAAAAAaAA1A11a", "sub": "111111111-1111-1111-1111-11111111", "roles": [ "Organization Administrator" ], "iss": "https://hostname/oidc", "groups": [ "ALL USERS" ], "preferred_username": "testuser@vcd-ms1", "nonce": "ab123acab", "aud": "33333333-3333-3333-3333-33333333333", "azp": "22222222-2222-2222-2222-22222222", "org_id": "12345678-1234-1234-1234-123456789abc", "org_display_name": "oidcorg", "name": "test user", "phone_number": " ", "exp": 1111111111, "org_name": "oidcorg", "iat": 1111111111, "email": "user1@vmware.com" } User Info response example:{ "sub": "111111111-1111-1111-1111-11111111", "preferred_username": "administrator", "name": "administrator user", "email": "user1@site.com", "phone_number": "0 (111) 222-3333", "roles": [ "system administrator" ], "groups": [], "org_name": "system", "org_display_name": "System Organization", "org_id": "12345678-1234-1234-1234-123456789abc" }

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/vcf-au.title: VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/vcf-au.description:
enables IT teams and cloud service providers (CSPs) to deliver a self-service private cloud for AI, Kubernetes, and VM-based applications.
The solution simplifies the process of provisioning and scaling a Multi-Tenant private cloud with out-of-the-box Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) offerings, accelerating the time to market for applications while maintaining control using policy-based governance.VCF Automation provides governance at the request and lifecycle level—controlling who can deploy which patterns, under what constraints and approvals—while runtime security, drift detection, and continuous enforcement are handled by downstream platforms.
Governance
#tenancyVCF Automation has the following capabilities:
Cloud Services: Provides a set of cloud services to meet the needs of application teams
Provider Management: Supports IT teams and cloud service providers to effectively manage, deliver, and scale cloud services across multiple vCenter and VCF instances.
Organization Management: Provides capabilities that enable the organization administrator of a Line of Business or a tenant to further organize and govern resources allocated to them among application teams.
vSphere Supervisor: Provides the capability to run Kubernetes workloads directly on ESX hosts and to create upstream Kubernetes clusters within dedicated namespaces.( #todo: Further explanation needed )

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.title: VCF Day 0 Tasks
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.description:
VMware Cloud Foundation Day 0 tasks are everything required to prepare and bootstrap the platform before any tenant, workload, or higher-level automation exists.
Think of Day 0 as laying the concrete and pouring the foundation—after this, you can build floors (VCF Day 1 Tasks) and move people in (VCF Day 2 Tasks). Day 0: Make the platform exist Day 1: Configure and extend the platform Day 2: Operate workloads on the platform VCF is very opinionated: nothing meaningful can happen until Day 0 is clean and correct.These are outside VCF but mandatory. Rack & cable hosts Power, cooling, BIOS/firmware NTP, DNS, IPAM VLANs / MTU (often jumbo frames) Out-of-band management (iDRAC / iLO) If this is wrong, everything later becomes “mysteriously flaky.”
Before VCF can orchestrate anything, ESX must exist.
Install ESX on all hosts Apply compatible firmware and drivers Validate hardware against VCF BOM Configure basic networking (vmnics, MTU) These hosts are raw compute, not yet part of any SDDC.This is the true start of VCF.
Deploy SDDC Manager Appliance Connect it to: DNS NTP Identity source Verify reachability to all ESX hosts From this point on, VCF owns lifecycle.This creates the core control plane SDDC.Includes automated deployment of:
vCenter Server
NSX Manager
vSAN
ESX Management Cluster This is where VCF becomes a self-hosting platform.After this, you no longer treat components individually.Baseline platform networking is established.
NSX fabric initialization Transport zones Edge nodes (management edges) Tier-0 / Tier-1 gateways Initial firewall policies This defines how everything can talk later.Foundational access control.
Integrate vCenter / SDDC Manager with: LDAP / AD / Identity Provider Define platform admin roles Secure service accounts Without this, automation has no authority.Often underestimated, always painful if skipped. CA strategy (internal vs external) TLS certificates for:
vCenter
NSX
SDDC Manager Trust alignment across components This is where future mTLS, OIDC, and zero-trust efforts live or die.This is about future safety. Validate VCF BOM Enable lifecycle management workflows Confirm patching & upgrade paths Confirm supportability state
If skipped, VCF Day 2 Tasks turns into firefighting. No tenants No projects No Supervisor Namespaces No Kubernetes workloads No automation pipelines No business logic Day 0 is pure platform plumbing. VCF Day 0 = platform existence It is non-negotiable and opinionated Focuses on infrastructure, identity, network, and lifecycle No tenants, no workloads, no business logic
Done right → VCF Day 1 Tasks and VCF Day 2 Tasks feel boring (the best outcome)

headers.heading: Core Categories of VCF Day 0 Tasks

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Day-N Operations/VCF Day 0 Tasks.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.title: VCF Day 1 Tasks
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.description:
VMware Cloud Foundation Day 1 tasks start after the platform exists and focus on making it usable, consumable, and policy-driven—without yet running real business workloads.If Day 0 pours concrete, Day 1 frames the building and installs utilities. Day 0 → Platform exists Day 1 → Platform is configurable & consumable Day 2 → Platform is used & operated Day 1 is where intent, policy, and abstraction appear.This is where business structure enters the system.
Define Organizations
Define Projects Map projects to: Supervisor Namespaces Resource boundaries Define quotas and limits This is not Kubernetes yet—it’s VCF’s business abstraction layer.From “admins only” to multi-role access.
Define Tenant Admin roles Map identity groups to roles Separate:
Platform Admins
Tenant Admins Developers Enable delegated self-service
This is where “secure Multi-Tenancy” becomes real.Networking shifts from fabric to consumption. Project-level networking Tenant Tier-1 gateways NAT, routing, firewall policies Load balancer enablement Network isolation per project Infrastructure networking (Day 0) becomes tenant networking.Turn raw storage into governed capacity. Define storage policies (performance, availability)
Assign policies to Projects
Enable vSAN / NFS / VMFS consumption Set quotas and constraints This prevents noisy neighbors and capacity abuse.Expose compute without exposing chaos. Define resource pools Assign clusters to projects Enable placement policies
Configure HA / DRS behavior Compute becomes schedulable capacity, not hardware.This is where container platforms appear.
Enable vSphere Supervisor Configure:
Supervisor Namespaces Kubernetes versions CNI / CSI integration
VKS clusters
Kubernetes exists because Day 1 enabled it, not because ESX magically does containers.Where humans stop clicking.
Enable VCF Automation
Define Blueprints Approval flows Day-1 actions exposed as APIs
Service Catalog creation This is the front door for tenants.This is preventative control, not enforcement after damage. Quotas Naming standards Placement constraints Lifecycle constraints Compliance policies Day 1 policies determine how painful Day 2 is.Before workloads, you need visibility. Enable logging pipelines Metrics collection Alert baselines Capacity visibility You can’t operate what you can’t see. No real business workloads No app-specific tuning No scaling incidents No break/fix operations Day 1 is still design-heavy, not ops-heavy. VCF Day 1 = platform enablement
Introduces tenancy, policy, automation No real workloads yet Sets the rules for everything that follows Good Day 1 → boring, predictable Day 2

headers.heading: Core Categories of VCF Day 1 Tasks

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Day-N Operations/VCF Day 1 Tasks.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.title: VCF Day 2 Tasks
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.description:
VMware Cloud Foundation Day 2 tasks begin once real workloads exist. This is where theory meets entropy: failures happen, usage grows, humans make mistakes, and the platform must keep working anyway.If: Day 0 pours the concrete Day 1 frames the building Day 2 is living in it for years Or: Day 0 → Existence Day 1 → Enablement Day 2 → Sustainment Day 2 is continuous, not a phase you “finish”.This is the obvious part—but it’s only the surface. Deploy workloads (VMs, Pods, clusters) Scale up/down Start / stop / suspend Migrate workloads Retire workloads Day 2 starts the feedback loop. Platform health monitoring Workload health monitoring Capacity tracking Performance baselines Alert tuning (noise reduction) Bad alerts = ignored alerts = outages.The real test of architecture. Host failures Network partitions Storage degradation Control plane issues Application outages Includes: [HA] / [DRS] behavior Failover validation Backup & restore DR testing If this fails, Day 0 and Day 1 didn’t matter.Security shifts from design to enforcement. Certificate rotation Secret rotation Credential revocation Firewall rule changes Vulnerability remediation Audit and compliance reporting One of VCF’s core promises.
ESX patching
vCenter upgrades
NSX upgrades Kubernetes version upgrades Firmware alignment (BOM compliance) All while: Workloads are running SLAs are enforced This is why VCF is opinionated.Reality: resources are finite. Capacity planning Quota adjustments Overcommit tuning Chargeback / showback Cluster expansion This is where finance meets engineering.Day 1 defines policies. Day 2 fights drift. Detect misconfigurations Enforce standards Handle exceptions Reconcile “special cases” Without this, entropy wins.Day 2 success is measured socially, not technically. Self-service reliability Automation success rates Time-to-resource Support ticket volume Developer trust A stable platform feels boring. That’s success.Day 2 never freezes architecture. Introduce new workload types Add regions / clusters Enable new services Deprecate old patterns VCF must evolve without reset. VCF Day 2 = continuous operations Includes incidents, upgrades, security, scale
Validates Day 0 and Day 1 decisions Workload type becomes irrelevant Boring Day 2 is the highest compliment

headers.heading: Core Categories of VCF Day 2 Tasks
Day 0 / Day 1 / Day 2 in One View

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: vCenter Roles for Supervisor Namespaces
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description: The VCF 9.0 release introduces a new role called Supervisor Administrator. The Supervisor Administrator role is granted by default to members of Administrators group on the Namespaces resource pool and folder in newly deployed Supervisors instead of the Read-only role in the prior versions.Based on the vCenter role assigned within the Supervisor inventory, a user or group can be assigned one of the following roles:Administrator RoleAs a vSphere Administrator, you can view and manage the vSphere infrastructure, including VKS clusters, vSphere Pods and VM service VMs.The vSphere Administrator has the membership of the "Administrators SSO Group".This Administrators group is automatically assigned the Supervisor Administrator role on the Supervisor hierarchy.Supervisor Administrator RoleA Supervisor Administrator role can only be assigned on the Supervisor folder.You will be able to view the namespaces inventory only after assigning it the Read-only role on the Cluster.When the Supervisor Administrator role is assigned on the Supervisor folder, a context is created that givess access only to cluster level resources in the Supervisor and not the vSphere Namespace. That is, you cannot list or view vSphere Namespaces. To be able to view vSphere Namespaces when you log in through VCF CLI, you must have permissions on the specific vSphere Namespace.Namespace Owner/Edit/View RoleIn this role, you are a consumer of the vSphere Namespace and can provision VKS clusters and vSphere Pods using kubectl.Given the Supervisor cluster IP address, you can login and start deploying and managing workloads on the vSphere Namespace you have been granted access to.Depending on the resource, you will have the following access:vCenter Privileges on Supervisor and vSphere NamespacesvCenter privileges control how you interact with vSphere Supervisor. You can set a privilege at different levels in the hierarchy. For example, if you set a privilege at the folder level, you can propagate the privilege to one or more objects within the folder. The object listed in the Required On column must have the privilege set, either directly or inherited.The Supervisor Administrator role has the following privileges:The Namespaces Owner role has the following privileges:Namespaces View PrivilegesNamespace Edit Privileges

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: VCF Single Sign-On
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description:
Authentication in VMware Cloud Foundation provides identity and access management services to VCF fleet components. You build your authentication design by using three main pillars - your external Identity Provider (IdP), VMware Cloud Foundation Identity Broker, and VMware Cloud Foundation Single Sign-On.Your corporate identity provider is the centralized source of digital identities for your enterprise, which provides authentication and identity assertion. You connect the corporate identity provider to your VCF fleet components by using VCF Identity Broker
VMware Identity BrokerVCF Identity Broker enables a VCF Single Sign-On implementation and streamlines authentication across different VCF fleet components, except for the SDDC Manager. The last pillar of this design uses VCF Single Sign-On to provide centralized authentication, identity federation, and user management.VCF Single Sign-On ModelsTo accommodate multiple VCF Instances as your VMware Cloud Foundation platform grows, you make design decisions regarding the placement and size of the VCF Identity Broker service. These decisions impact the scale, availability, blast radius, and span of your VCF Single Sign-On environment.VCF Single Sign-On Models in  VMware Cloud Foundation |Model|Attributes|Benefits|Implications| |---|---|---|---| |VCF Fleet-Wide Single Sign-On Model|Single VCF Identity Broker instance per VCF fleet.|Provides VCF Single Sign-On capabilities across all components in VCF fleet.|Single point of failure for the authentication service for a VCF fleet.x

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: Developing Workflows with VCF Operations Orchestrator
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description: Workflow development involves using the workflow editor in VCF Operations orchestrator, the Orchestrator APIs, and the JavaScript, Python, Node.js, and PowerShell scripting languages.What does the workflow development involve?The process for developing a custom workflow involves a series of steps. Depending on the type of workflow that you are developing, you might follow a different sequence of step or skip a step. For example, you can create a workflow without custom scripting.Generally, developing a workflow involves the following steps. Create a new workflow or create a duplicate of an existing workflow from the standard library. Provide general information about the workflow. Define the input and output parameters of the workflow. Lay out and link the workflow schema to define the logical flow of the workflow. Bind the input and output parameters of each schema element to workflow variables. Write the necessary scripts for scriptable task elements or custom decision elements. Create the workflow presentation from the  Input Form  tab. Validate the workflow. Practices for developing workflowsYou can follow best practices for developing Orchestrator workflows by multiple users and in a clustered environment. Each developer has a dedicated test standalone Orchestrator instance for creating and developing workflows. As VCF Automation can only have single Orchestrator instance integrated to it, this should be a separate standalone instance. Workflows are saved as maven projects on a shared source code control system. To ensure optimal performance of the Orchestrator production deployment, it is best to import workflows in a scheduled period. Working with the workflow editorYou create and edit workflows in the Orchestrator workflow editor. The workflow editor is the Integrated Development Environment (IDE) of VCF Operations orchestrator for developing workflows.The workflow editor consists of tabs where you edit the components of your workflows. Summary. Provide general information about the workflow, such as the workflow name, description, tags, and version number. The Summary tab can also be used to configure the server restart behavior and workflow run failure behavior. Variables. Define the variables for your workflow. Variables were previously known as attributes. Input/Output. Define the input and output parameters of your workflow. The input parameters provide the data that the workflow processes during the workflow run. The output parameters are provided when the workflow run finishes. Schema. Build your workflow by dragging workflow schema elements from the workflow palette on the left side of the Schema tab. By clicking an element in the schema diagram, you can define and edit the element's behavior. Input Form. Define the layout of the user input dialog box that appears when users run a workflow. You arrange the parameters and variables into presentation steps and tabs to ease identification of parameters in the input parameters dialog box. You define the constraints on the input parameters that users can provide in the presentation by setting the parameter properties. You can also add external validation for your workflow by using actions. Version History. View and manage the version history of the workflow. Compare and restore versions and push and pull workflows to and from your integrated Git repository. Audit. View information about events related to the workflow such as, when it was saved, when a workflow run was performed, and when a workflow run was finished.

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: Key Workflow Concepts
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description: Workflows consist of a schema, workflow variables, and input and output parameters. The workflow schema is the main component of a workflow as it defines all the workflow elements and the logical connections between them. The workflow variables and parameters are the properties that workflows use to transfer data. VCF Operations orchestrator saves a workflow token every time a workflow runs, recording the details of that specific workflow run.Workflow ParametersWorkflows receive input parameters and generate output parameters when they run.Input ParametersMost workflows require a certain set of input parameters to run. An input parameter is an argument that the workflow processes when it runs. The user, an application, another workflow, or an action passes input parameters to a workflow for the workflow to process when it runs.For example, if a workflow resets a virtual machine, the workflow requires the name of the virtual machine as an input parameter.Output ParametersA workflow's output parameters represent the result from the workflow run. Output parameters can change when a workflow or a workflow element runs. During a workflow run, the workflow can receive the output parameters of other workflows as input parameters.For example, if a workflow creates a snapshot of a virtual machine, the output parameter for the workflow is the resulting snapshot.Workflow VariablesWorkflow elements process data that they receive as input parameters, and set the resulting data as workflow variables or output parameters.Read-only workflow variables act as global constants for a workflow. Writable variables act as a workflow’s global variables.You can use variables to transfer data between the elements of a workflow. You can obtain variables in the following ways: Define variables when you create a workflow. Set the output parameter of a workflow element as a workflow variable. Inherit variables from a configuration element. Workflow SchemaA workflow schema is a graphical representation that shows the workflow as a flow diagram of interconnected workflow elements. The workflow schema is the most important element of a workflow as it determines its logic.Workflow PresentationWhen users run a workflow, they provide the values for the input parameters of the workflow in the workflow presentation. When you organize the workflow presentation, consider the type and number of input parameters of the workflow. You can configure the presentation of your workflows from the Input Form tab of the workflow editor.Workflow TokensA workflow token represents a workflow that is running or has finished running.A workflow is an abstract description of a process that defines a generic sequence of steps and a generic set of required input parameters. When you run a workflow with a set of input parameters, you receive an instance of this abstract workflow that behaves according to the specific input parameters you give it. This specific instance of a finished or a running workflow is called a workflow token.Workflow Token AttributesWorkflow token attributes are the specific parameters with which a workflow token runs. The workflow token attributes are an aggregation of the workflow's global variables and the specific input and output parameters with which you run the workflow token.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Platform Operations and Services/Platform Services and Management/Key Workflow Concepts.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: Running VCF Operations Orchestrator Workflows
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description: A VCF Operations orchestrator workflow runs according to a logical flow of events.When you run a workflow, each schema element in the workflow runs according to the following sequence. The workflow binds the workflow token variables and input parameters to the input parameters of the schema element. The schema element runs. The output parameters of the schema element are copied to the workflow token variables and workflow output parameters. The workflow token variables and output parameters are stored in the database. The next schema element starts running. This sequence repeats for each schema element until the end of the workflow.Workflow Token Check PointsWhen a workflow runs, each schema element is a check point. After each schema element runs, VCF Operations orchestrator stores workflow token variables in the database, and the next schema element starts running. If the workflow stops unexpectedly, the next time the Orchestrator server restarts, the currently active schema element runs again, and the workflow continues from the start of the schema element that was running when the interruption occurred. However, VCF Operations orchestrator does not implement transaction management or a rollback function.End of WorkflowThe workflow ends if the current active schema element is an end element. After the workflow reaches an end element, other workflows or applications can use the output parameters of the workflow.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Platform Operations and Services/Platform Services and Management/Running VCF Operations Orchestrator Workflows.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: VCF Operations Orchestrator
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description: Managing WorkflowsLast Updated December 16, 2025A workflow is a series of actions and decisions that you run sequentially. VCF Operations orchestrator provides a library of workflows that perform common management tasks. VCF Operations orchestrator also provides libraries of the individual actions that the workflows perform.Workflows combine actions, decisions, and results that, when performed in a particular order, finish a specific task or a specific process in a virtual environment. Workflows perform tasks such as provisioning virtual machines, backing up, performing regular maintenance, sending emails, performing SSH operations, managing the physical infrastructure, and other general utility operations. Workflows accept inputs according to their function. You can create workflows that run according to defined schedules, or that run if certain anticipated events occur. Information can be provided by you, by other users, by another workflow or action, or by an external process such as a Web service call from an application. Workflows perform some validation and filtering of information before they run.Workflows can call upon other workflows. For example, you can have workflow that calls up another workflow to create a new virtual machine.You create workflows by using the VCF Operations orchestrator interface’s integrated development environment (IDE), that provides access to the workflow library and the ability to run workflows on the workflow engine. The workflow engine can also take objects from external libraries that you plug in to VCF Operations orchestrator. This feature allows you to customize processes or implement functions that third-party applications provide.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Platform Operations and Services/Platform Services and Management/VCF Operations Orchestrator.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.title: VCF Operations HCX
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.description:
VCF Operations HCX is VMware’s integrated workload mobility and migration platform built into VMware Cloud Foundation. It combines the power of VMware Hybrid Cloud Extension (HCX) with VCF’s operational tooling to simplify application migration, workload rebalancing, and business continuity across data centers and clouds.You can perform secure and automated migrations without requiring changes to applications or network configurations.Thus, you can place workloads based on business requirements. The platform minimizes downtime during migrations, improves scalability, and supports compliance and security throughout workload transitions.
HCX stands for Hybrid Cloud eXtension—it’s not just another name for vMotion. It’s a comprehensive application mobility platform from VMware that enables workload migration, workload rebalancing, and business continuity across data centers and clouds.VCF Operations HCX has the following capabilities: Seamless workload migration. Migrate VMs and applications in waves live or in bulk with minimal or zero downtime. Network extension. Extend networks while preserving IP addresses and topologies to maintain application connectivity. Inter-and intra-VCF mobility. Enable workload mobility within and across multiple VCF instances, including site-to-site and region-to-region migrations. Application placement optimization. Enables high-performance application mobility across different environments, making it easier to optimize workload placement based on business requirements. At its heart, VCF Operations HCX is an application mobility platform that: **Connects environments—on-premises data centers, private clouds, and public clouds—with optimized, secure network interconnectivity. Enables workload migration—live or bulk migration of virtual machines (VMs) and applications between environments with minimal downtime. Supports hybrid cloud adoption—making it easier to modernize, consolidate, or balance workloads across sites. Essentially, it extends the capabilities of VCF so that moving workloads into, out of, or around your VCF estate is seamless and automated.VCF Operations HCX automates the process of moving VMs and applications from one environment to another. This includes: Live migrations (zero or near-zero downtime) Bulk migrations for large-scale moves Cross-platform migrations (including non-vSphere sources in some scenarios) Network extension so IPs/MACs remain consistent during migration This makes migrations faster, less error-prone, and less disruptive than traditional approaches.HCX builds a secure, encrypted interconnect between sites that: Extends Layer-2 networks across sites Preserves VM networking so that workloads keep their addresses Provides optimized tunnels tailored for high-speed bulk movement Cloud adoption isn’t a one-time event — usage patterns change. HCX enables: Moving workloads based on performance needs Rebalancing for cost or compliance reasons Continuous optimization of where workloads run This is key in hybrid environments where business needs or performance requirements evolve over time.VCF Operations HCX has deeper integration with VCF: Unified management & single sign-on with other VCF components Shared licensing managed through VCF Operations Integrated planning & execution workflows with VCF Operations for Networks Easier deployment with a single unified HCX Manager appliance That means less separate manual setup and a smoother experience from discovery to execution.Imagine you’re relocating a city’s services (libraries, police stations, hospitals) to a new smart city: Traditional migration = manually moving each building piece by piece. VCF Operations HCX = building a dedicated transit corridor where services can shift live without interruption, while preserving all their connections and addresses — all orchestrated by a central operations dashboard instead of manual labor.
vMotion is VMware’s native live-migration technology for moving a running VM between ESX hosts (including memory and CPU state), usually within the same VCF Domain or cluster.HCX doesn’t replace vMotion; it leverages it as one migration method (called “HCX vMotion”) when moving workloads between HCX-connected sites. It also supports: Cold Migration: Powered-off VMs Bulk Migration: Parallel, batched workloads Replication-Assisted vMotion: Parallel live migrations via replication + vMotion So, vMotion is a component inside HCX’s larger orchestration and connectivity framework. VCF Operations HCX is VMware’s integrated workload mobility solution within VMware Cloud Foundation. It simplifies application migration and workload rebalancing across on-prem, hybrid, and multi-cloud environments. Via optimized network extension and interconnects, it preserves application connectivity and minimizes disruption. Recent integrations with VCF improve deployment, management, and operational workflows. If you want, I can explain specific HCX migration types or dive into how this works step-by-step during a VCF rollout.

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.title: VMware Live Recovery
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.description:
VMware Live Recovery is VMware’s modern, unified disaster-recovery (DR) and cyber-recovery capability, designed to protect VCF-managed workloads against outages, site failures, and ransomware, with minimal downtime and minimal data loss. VMware Live Recovery = continuous protection + fast failover + clean recovery, natively aligned with VCF operations. VMware Live Recovery is not a hypervisor feature and not just storage replication.It lives at the platform services / operations layer of VCF. Site failure Cluster outage Maintenance windows gone wrong Encrypted VMs Malicious data corruption Need for clean rollback instead of “latest replica” Near-zero RPO (seconds) Change-block tracking Continuous replication rather than periodic snapshots Automated failover / failback Application-aware recovery ordering Network remapping and IP preservation Roll back to a known-good state Avoid restoring infected replicas Immutable recovery points (depending on backing storage) Protect workloads: on-prem → on-prem on-prem → cloud cloud → cloud Strong alignment with hybrid VCF deployments Primarily: VM workloads vSAN-backed storage VCF-managed domains It is not: A Kubernetes-native backup system A replacement for application-level backups A secrets-or-identity-recovery tool ^ all these remain separate concerns.You can think of VCF as enforcing invariants: “Workloads must be recoverable within defined SLOs.” VMware Live Recovery is the enforcement mechanism for the resilience invariant: If a site fails → recover If data is corrupted → rewind safely If ransomware hits → recover clean, fast, and confidently VLR is
Not vMotion
Not VCF Operations HCX Not a backup product Not a Kubernetes-native DR Those solve mobility or data protection, not platform-level resilience orchestration. VMware Live Recovery is VCF’s unified DR + cyber-recovery platform Designed for low RPO, fast RTO, and clean recovery Successor mindset to SRM, built for ransomware-era threats Operates at the VCF Operations layer, not the hypervisor Focused on VM workloads, not containers or apps directly

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/vcf-op.title: VCF Operations
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/vcf-op.description:
VCF Operations helps your organization build, manage, operate and secure your private cloud infrastructure by deploying and maintaining its fleet-level components, providing visibility and enhanced performance across the workload and infrastructure stack, and helping your organization stay compliant with regulatory standards and organizational guidelines.VCF Operations has these functional areas: Fleet Management Enables operational consistency and efficient resource management of the VCF infrastructure at scale.
Operations Management Provides monitoring and optimization of performance, cost and capacity, and faster troubleshooting.
Workload Operations  Ensures that critical applications are running as expected.
Performance Monitoring Ensures applications have continuous access to resources
FinOps and Capacity Helps you analyze your infrastructure expenses and optimize capacity usage.
VCF Operations HCX Provides support for migrating and interconnecting workloads within and across VCF private cloud.
Security Management Provides security management to ensure that your VCF private cloud is operationally secure.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/vcf-op.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/control-planes/vcloud-director/vclou.title: vCloud Director 1
vcf/control-planes/vcloud-director/vclou.description:
VMware vCloud Director (VCD) is a cloud-management and multi-tenancy layer built on top of vSphere. It was designed primarily for service providers (ISPs, telcos, MSPs) to offer VMware-based clouds to multiple customers in a clean, isolated, self-service way. vSphere → virtualization engine (hypervisors, clusters, VMs) VCD → cloud abstraction + multi-tenant control plane VCF → opinionated full stack (compute + storage + networking + ops) vSphere does not have native multitenancy, VCD enables multitenancy. VCD → sell VMware-based cloud to others VCF Automation → run your own internal cloud Cloud Layer ──────────── vCloud Director ← multi-tenant cloud manager Automation Layer ──────────── VCF Automation / Aria Automation Infrastructure ──────────── vSphere + vSAN + NSX Hardware ──────────── Bare metal


No. vSphere = hypervisor + cluster management VCD = separate product that consumes vSphere
VMware’s product web pages for Cloud Director explicitly state that VCD operates within the VMware Cloud Foundation platform as an integrated cloud-management layer: VCD is described as helping to “[efficiently […] operate and manage your managed private and public cloud services using VMware Cloud Director within the VMware Cloud Foundation platform](VMware Cloud Director | Leading Cloud Service Delivery Platform.However, in the baseline VCF component lists and core architectural docs, the docs list things like vSphere, vSAN, NSX, SDDC Manager, VCF Automation but not VCD as a base building block. *Historically: no. Today: “it depends on the SKU and use case.”** VMware Cloud Foundation (VCF) is aimed at: Enterprises Private cloud Platform teams
Automation (VCF Automation) VMware vCloud Director (VCD) is aimed at: Service providers Telcos Hosted private cloud Customer-facing tenancy VCF does not require VCD, and most enterprise VCF deployments do not use it.

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx.html.title: NSX
vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx.html.description:
Use **NSX** as a network administrator for networking and automation for virtual machines, containers, or bare metal applications.NSX enables network connectivity, operations, and scale. It uses a software-defined approach to networking that spans data centers, clouds and application frameworks.NSX brings networking services closer to the application, whether running on virtual machines (VMs), containers or physical servers. This allows for a cloud operating model where networks can be provisioned and managed independently of the underlying hardware.NSX abstracts network services from the underlying hardware, enabling programmable infrastructure through APIs. You can implement policies and workflows to automate tasks like network provisioning, security enforcement, load balancing, streamlining operations, and improving efficiency.NSX provides a complete set of logical networking capabilities and services, including logical switching, routing, distributed load balancing, virtual private network (VPN), quality of service (QoS), and monitoring.Enable logical Layer 2 overlay extensions across a routed (Layer 3) fabric within and across data center boundaries.Dynamic routing between virtual networks that is performed in a distributed manner in the hypervisor kernel, and scale-out routing with active-active failover with physical routers. Static routing and dynamic routing protocols are supported, including support for IPv6.Complete data plane isolation among tenants with a separate routing table, network address translation (NAT), and edge firewall support in each VRF on the Support for bridging between VLANs configured on the physical network and NSX overlay networks, for seamless connectivity between virtual and physical workloads.Site-to-site and unmanaged VPN for cloud gateway services.By using NSX, you can move workloads between racks and data centers by decoupling them from the underlying networks.Centralized policy configuration and enforcement across multiple locations from a single pane of glass, enabling network-wide consistent policy, operational simplicity, and simplified disaster recovery architecture.Enable consistent networking and security across data center sites, and across private cloud boundaries, irrespective of underlying physical topology or cloud platform.NSX can manage the provisioning, deployment, operations and retirement of networking infrastructure and applications from a central control pane. You can automate infrastructure operations and offload manual tasks with workflows and agile templating using tools such as VCF Automation, Terraform, and Ansible. 
VPCs provide isolated network environments within a shared infrastructure. You can use Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) constructs to provision and manage network resources to business units or project teams independently, with granular control over networking policies and resource allocation.
By creating projects, you can isolate security and networking objects across tenants in a single NSX deployment. You enable multi-tenant deployment and consumption of NSX services for the provider administrator and the tenants or organizations.
The provider administrator can create projects, assign users and groups, and allocate quotas to restrict the configurations available to the tenants.
#tenancy

vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/vsan.html.title: vSAN
vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/vsan.html.description:
vSAN aggregates local or direct-attached capacity devices of all ESX hosts in a cluster and creates a single storage pool shared across all ESX hosts in the  vSAN cluster.Use **vSAN** as a VI administrator or storage administrator to enhance storage performance by aggregating local storage into a single shared pool across all hosts in a vSAN cluster.
You can use vSphere features that require shared storage, such as vSphere HA, vSphere vMotion, and vSphere DRS, without the need for external shared storage.vSAN provides operational consistency from edge to cloud, with complete visibility and lifecycle management of compute and storage from a single UI.You can perform consistent, VM-centric operations by using policy-based management. Within the vSAN ESA, per-VM policies increase flexibility of management, enabling compression policies, or customize data services on a per-VM basis.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/vsan.html.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/access-and-int.title: vSphere Client
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/access-and-int.description:
vSphere Client is: A web UI (HTML / JS) Running inside either ESX (embedded) or vCenter Consuming backend APIs It consumes REST and legacy SOAP / internal APIs Functionally: It is an API consumer It behaves differently depending on where it is placed: Same UI codebase: Connected to ESX → host-scoped Connected to vCenter Server → environment-scoped The UI is not “smart”: The backend defines reality.
There is exactly ONE UI name (“vSphere Client”), but it can connect to TWO different backends.
vCenter Server
ESX Hosts ## Mode 1 Browser ↓ ESX Host ↓ Embedded vSphere Client ## Mode 2 Browser ↓ vCenter Server ↓ vSphere Client ↓ Many ESX hosts
You might want to check out vCenter Server, one of the core components that makes vSphere, vSphere.
